results.title: English mahogany and brass bi-unial magic lantern
results.brief_description: The magic lantern is an important ancestor of cinema. Developed in the 1600s, magic lanterns use a light source, lenses and transparent slides to project religious, educational or entertaining scenes and stories. Bi-unial lanterns use two lenses to create the illusion of movement.

constellations_primary.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_primary.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

results.title_for_label: English mahogany and brass bi-unial magic lantern
results.description:
The magic lantern is an important ancestor of cinema. Developed in the 1600s, magic lanterns use a light source, lenses and transparent slides to project religious, educational or entertaining scenes and stories.

Originally, lanternists used candles or gaslight to illuminate their slides, which usually limited their projections to one lens. When limelight was invented in the 1800s, it not only produced brighter, clearer projections but also allowed lanternists to control the light source, leading to more creative approaches and inventions. One was the bi-unial lantern, like this one, which uses two lenses to superimpose different slides onto the same screen to create the illusion of time or movement.
description_for_label:
The magic lantern is an important ancestor of cinema. Developed in the 1600s, magic lanterns use a light source, lenses and transparent slides to project religious, educational or entertaining scenes and stories.

Originally, lanternists used candles or gaslight to illuminate their slides, which usually limited their projections to one lens. When limelight was invented in the 1800s, it not only produced brighter, clearer projections but also allowed lanternists to control the light source, leading to more creative approaches and inventions. One was the bi-unial lantern, like this one, which uses two lenses to superimpose different slides onto the same screen to create the illusion of time or movement.

results.title: Arrival of film
results.brief_description: A compilation of different scenes from the beginning of cinema.

constellations_primary.name: Film firsts
constellations_primary.description: The early days of cinema were an exciting period of experimentation, with many inventors racing to come up with their own moving-image devices.

results.description: Louis Le Prince shot the first film on a single lens camera in 1888. But before his contribution was recognised, the French inventor mysteriously disappeared and has been largely forgotten. Thomas Edison wasn’t forgotten though. After revealing his Kinetoscope in 1893, crowds lined up to watch short films through a peephole. Housed in a large cabinet, the Kinetoscope contained 50-foot loops of 35mm film that showed everything from barber shops to bodybuilding. In 1895, moving images broke free with the Lumiere Brothers’ Cinematographe, a device that could record, develop and project film onto a screen for public viewing. It even inspired the name of the new art form – cinema.
description_for_label: Louis Le Prince shot the first film on a single lens camera in 1888. But before his contribution was recognised, the French inventor mysteriously disappeared and has been largely forgotten. Thomas Edison wasn’t forgotten though. After revealing his Kinetoscope in 1893, crowds lined up to watch short films through a peephole. Housed in a large cabinet, the Kinetoscope contained 50-foot loops of 35mm film that showed everything from barber shops to bodybuilding. In 1895, moving images broke free with the Lumiere Brothers’ Cinematographe, a device that could record, develop and project film onto a screen for public viewing. It even inspired the name of the new art form – cinema.

results.title: Flip book [interactive]
results.brief_description:
An interactive allowing visitors to make their own flip books that can be saved to their Lens. Visitors can also purchase printed versions of their flip books in the ACMI Shop.

Visitors stand in front of flipbook maker and select ‘record’, they are then advised to ‘get ready’.

When recording, a count down timer will advise of how long visitors have left.

Visitors can then save their flipbook to their lens and then proceed to the ACMI shop for printing.

This interactive was re-booted from ACMI’s previous exhibition “Screen Worlds” because it was a crowd favourite. The design of the interactive and flipbook has been updated.

results.title: Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed)
results.brief_description: While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Lotte Reiniger’s The Adventures of Prince Achmed precedes the Disney film by over a decade.

constellations_primary.name: Shadowplay and spookiness
constellations_primary.description: Silhouettes and shadows scare up some of the most sinister creatures in cinema and videogames.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
constellations_other.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

constellations_other.name: Storytelling through shadow play
constellations_other.description: Shadow play has brought stories to life for thousands of years and is still used today.

results.title_for_label: Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed)
results.description:
You may not have heard of German animator Lotte Reiniger. She turned her home into a DIY animation studio and pioneered animating silhouettes by shooting homemade puppets frame-by-frame against sheets of lead.

Later she used layers of glass to create depth, devising the first multiplane camera, which she used to create the first colour animated feature film, The Adventures of Prince Achmed (1926). While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Reiniger’s fairytale precedes the Disney film by over a decade. With more than 60 animated films to her name, Lotte Reiniger is a true hero of animation.
description_for_label:
You may not have heard of German animator Lotte Reiniger. She turned her home into a DIY animation studio and pioneered animating silhouettes by shooting homemade puppets frame-by-frame against sheets of lead.

Later she used layers of glass to create depth, devising the first multiplane camera, which she used to create the first colour animated feature film, The Adventures of Prince Achmed (1926). While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Reiniger’s fairytale precedes the Disney film by over a decade. With more than 60 animated films to her name, Lotte Reiniger is a true hero of animation.

results.title: Natalie Kalmus
results.brief_description: When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939).

constellations_primary.name: Communicating colour
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of colour on-screen inspired by Technicolor supervisor, Natalie Kalmus.

results.description:
When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939) and Gone with the Wind (1939).

After seeing filmmakers use the earlier two-strip Technicolor process to produce “unnatural and disastrous results”, she urged filmmakers to employ “colour restraint”. Kalmus believed that colour theories used in paintings could also be used in film and encouraged filmmakers to carefully consider which colours would convey a story’s emotions and themes.
description_for_label:
When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939) and Gone with the Wind (1939).

After seeing filmmakers use the earlier two-strip Technicolor process to produce “unnatural and disastrous results”, she urged filmmakers to employ “colour restraint”. Kalmus believed that colour theories used in paintings could also be used in film and encouraged filmmakers to carefully consider which colours would convey a story’s emotions and themes.

results.title: Charlie Chaplin
results.brief_description: Charlie Chaplin is one of the most important people in the history of cinema. From The Kid (1921) to Modern Times (1936), his filmography features groundbreaking and critically acclaimed movies.
results.description:
Charlie Chaplin is one of the most important people in the history of cinema. From The Kid (1921) to Modern Times (1936), his filmography features groundbreaking and critically acclaimed movies.

Aside from being a writer, director, composer and producer, Chaplin is best known as a comic performer and was the first person to popularise feature-length comedies. His slapstick vagrant character ‘the Tramp’ is one of the most iconic performances in movie history and embodies Chaplin’s compassion for the downtrodden. His films often made fun of the wealthy and powerful, likely contributing to Chaplin being blacklisted from Hollywood in 1948 for having Communist sympathies.
description_for_label:
Charlie Chaplin is one of the most important people in the history of cinema. From The Kid (1921) to Modern Times (1936), his filmography features groundbreaking and critically acclaimed movies.

Aside from being a writer, director, composer and producer, Chaplin is best known as a comic performer and was the first person to popularise feature-length comedies. His slapstick vagrant character ‘the Tramp’ is one of the most iconic performances in movie history and embodies Chaplin’s compassion for the downtrodden. results.title: Fritz Lang
results.brief_description: Fritz Lang was a visionary German director who established many science fiction tropes with his silent masterpiece Metropolis (1927). If that wasn’t enough, Lang’s seminal crime drama M (1931) was an early progenitor of psychological thrillers and serial killer films.

constellations_primary.name: One of the first auteurs
constellations_primary.description: A progenitor of modern film genres such as sci-fi, psychological thriller and serial killer films decades before such terms were coined, Austrian-born director Fritz Lang also enjoyed the occasional on-screen meta-moment.

results.description: Fritz Lang was a visionary German director who established many science fiction tropes with his silent masterpiece Metropolis (1927). From a technologically advanced but nightmarish future to mad scientists and the first robot in a feature, Metropolis has influenced so much of what we see on-screen today. At two hours and 33 minutes, it was also one of the longest films ever made at the time. Critics were sceptical at first, but it’s now considered groundbreaking, particularly for its production design and costumes. Those two elements have inspired C-3PO in Star Wars, Kylie Minogue’s robotic stage costumes and the futuristic city in Blade Runner. If that wasn’t enough, Lang’s seminal crime drama M (1931) was an early progenitor of psychological thrillers and serial killer films.
description_for_label: Fritz Lang was a visionary German director who established many science fiction tropes with his silent masterpiece Metropolis (1927). From a technologically advanced but nightmarish future to mad scientists and the first robot in a feature, Metropolis has influenced so much of what we see on-screen today. At two hours and 33 minutes, it was also one of the longest films ever made at the time. Critics were sceptical at first, but it’s now considered groundbreaking, particularly for its production design and costumes. Those two elements have inspired C-3PO in Star Wars, Kylie Minogue’s robotic stage costumes and the futuristic city in Blade Runner. If that wasn’t enough, Lang’s seminal crime drama M (1931) was an early progenitor of psychological thrillers and serial killer films.
